simple_results: [{"detection_name": "Field Suggestions Enabled", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Information Disclosure", "description": "Field suggestions enabled - potential information disclosure", "evidence": "Found \"did you mean\" in error message - field suggestions are enabled"}]
llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: field_suggestions", "detection": "safe", "category": "Unknown", "description": "The GraphQL response returns field-level suggestion text (\"Did you mean 'name'?\", \"Did you mean 'logo'?\"), which leaks schema details about available fields. This is an information disclosure (field_suggestions) issue: an attacker can use these hints to enumerate correct field names and map the schema more quickly. While this does not directly execute code or access data by itself, it aids reconnaissance and can be combined with other techniques to craft more effective queries or attacks. Recommended mitigations: disable detailed error messages and suggestion text in production (turn off debug mode), return generic error messages, or configure the GraphQL server/library to suppress suggestion hints and limit schema exposure (e.g., restrict introspection or enforce authentication/authorization on schema endpoints).", "evidence": "Error messages: \"Cannot query field \\\"nme\\\" on type \\\"Serie\\\". Did you mean \\\"name\\\"?\" and \"Cannot query field \\\"logo_url\\\" on type \\\"Serie\\\". Did you mean \\\"logo\\\"?\"", "confidence": 0.9, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "field_suggestions", "severity": "LOW", "confidence": 0.9, "evidence": "Error messages: \"Cannot query field \\\"nme\\\" on type \\\"Serie\\\". Did you mean \\\"name\\\"?\" and \"Cannot query field \\\"logo_url\\\" on type \\\"Serie\\\". Did you mean \\\"logo\\\"?\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response returns field-level suggestion text (\"Did you mean 'name'?\", \"Did you mean 'logo'?\"), which leaks schema details about available fields. This is an information disclosure (field_suggestions) issue: an attacker can use these hints to enumerate correct field names and map the schema more quickly. While this does not directly execute code or access data by itself, it aids reconnaissance and can be combined with other techniques to craft more effective queries or attacks. Recommended mitigations: disable detailed error messages and suggestion text in production (turn off debug mode), return generic error messages, or configure the GraphQL server/library to suppress suggestion hints and limit schema exposure (e.g., restrict introspection or enforce authentication/authorization on schema endpoints)."}}]

[{"detection_name": "LLM: GraphQL introspection / schema information disclosure", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL error messages reveal internal schema details (type name 'Serie', field names 'types' and 'series', and argument names). This is an information disclosure / introspection-type vulnerability that assists in further targeted probing and exploitation. No evidence of SQLi, XSS, SSRF, path/OS command injection, or sensitive data leakage beyond schema metadata was observed in this response.", "evidence": "Error messages in response: \"Cannot query field \\\"types\\\" on type \\\"Serie\\\".\" and \"Unknown argument \\\"series\\\" on field \\\"Query.series\\\".\" plus field conflict message revealing field name \"series\".", "confidence": 0.9, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "GraphQL introspection / schema information disclosure", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.9, "evidence": "Error messages in response: \"Cannot query field \\\"types\\\" on type \\\"Serie\\\".\" and \"Unknown argument \\\"series\\\" on field \\\"Query.series\\\".\" plus field conflict message revealing field name \"series\".", "explanation": "The GraphQL error messages reveal internal schema details (type name 'Serie', field names 'types' and 'series', and argument names). Even if the built-in introspection query is disabled, returning descriptive GraphQL errors exposes the schema surface which can be used by an attacker to enumerate types, fields and valid arguments. This is an information disclosure / introspection-type vulnerability that assists in further targeted probing and exploitation. No evidence of SQLi, XSS, SSRF, path/OS command injection, or sensitive data leakage beyond schema metadata was observed in this response."}}]

[{"detection_name": "LLM: field_suggestions", "detection": "safe", "category": "Unknown", "description": "The GraphQL response returns a helpful suggestion revealing a valid field name ("name") when an invalid field ("nam") was queried. This is a field_suggestions information-disclosure issue: the server is exposing schema details that an attacker can use to enumerate and probe the GraphQL schema more efficiently. While this does not directly allow data exfiltration or command execution, it reduces the effort required for schema discovery and targeted queries.

Recommendation: suppress or remove field suggestion text in error responses in production, return generic validation errors instead, and enforce strict access control on schema/fields. Consider enabling validation/whitelisting or schema introspection controls if needed.", "evidence": "GraphQL error: "Cannot query field \"nam\" on type \"Serie\". Did you mean \"name\"?"", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "field_suggestions", "severity": "LOW", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "GraphQL error: "Cannot query field \"nam\" on type \"Serie\". Did you mean \"name\"?"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response returns a helpful suggestion revealing a valid field name ("name") when an invalid field ("nam") was queried. This is a field_suggestions information-disclosure issue: the server is exposing schema details that an attacker can use to enumerate and probe the GraphQL schema more efficiently. While this does not directly allow data exfiltration or command execution, it reduces the effort required for schema discovery and targeted queries.

Recommendation: suppress or remove field suggestion text in error responses in production, return generic validation errors instead, and enforce strict access control on schema/fields. Consider enabling validation/whitelisting or schema introspection controls if needed."}}]

[{"detection_name": "LLM: Information Disclosure", "detection": "safe", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response contains a backend exception string from an HTTP client (likely Python requests), exposing internal implementation details: the internal/external host name (api.tcgdex.net), the port, and the client's timeout setting. This is an information disclosure issue because it reveals infrastructure and error-handling behavior. While not directly showing SQL/XSS/command execution, such detailed errors can aid attackers in reconnaissance (identifying services, endpoints, and potential SSRF attack targets). Recommend returning generic error messages to clients, logging full details server-side only, and avoiding propagation of raw exception strings to API responses.", "evidence": "error: \"HTTPSConnectionPool(host='api.tcgdex.net', port=443): Read timed out. (read timeout=10)\"", "confidence": 0.9, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "Information Disclosure", "severity": "LOW", "confidence": 0.9, "evidence": "error: \"HTTPSConnectionPool(host='api.tcgdex.net', port=443): Read timed out. (read timeout=10)\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response contains a backend exception string from an HTTP client (likely Python requests), exposing internal implementation details: the internal/external host name (api.tcgdex.net), the port, and the client's timeout setting. This is an information disclosure issue because it reveals infrastructure and error-handling behavior. While not directly showing SQL/XSS/command execution, such detailed errors can aid attackers in reconnaissance (identifying services, endpoints, and potential SSRF attack targets). Recommend returning generic error messages to clients, logging full details server-side only, and avoiding propagation of raw exception strings to API responses."}}]

[{"detection_name": "LLM: introspection", "detection": "safe", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response reveals schema-related information: it identifies an existing field (Query.series) and reports that the supplied argument 'input' is unknown. This is a form of schema exposure/introspection leakage (even though it is not a full __schema introspection response), which allows an attacker to enumerate fields and valid arguments. The leakage is limited (single error message) but still provides useful reconnaissance. Mitigations: suppress detailed GraphQL errors in production, return generic error messages, restrict or disable introspection for unauthenticated users, and implement rate-limiting and logging to detect schema probing.", "evidence": "GraphQL error message: \"Unknown argument \\\"input\\\" on field \\\"Query.series\\\".\"", "confidence": 0.8, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "introspection", "severity": "LOW", "confidence": 0.8, "evidence": "GraphQL error message: \"Unknown argument \\\"input\\\" on field \\\"Query.series\\\".\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response reveals schema-related information: it identifies an existing field (Query.series) and reports that the supplied argument 'input' is unknown. This is a form of schema exposure/introspection leakage (even though it is not a full __schema introspection response), which allows an attacker to enumerate fields and valid arguments. The leakage is limited (single error message) but still provides useful reconnaissance. Mitigations: suppress detailed GraphQL errors in production, return generic error messages, restrict or disable introspection for unauthenticated users, and implement rate-limiting and logging to detect schema probing."}}]

[{"detection_name": "LLM: xss_injection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response error includes the raw user-supplied string containing a <script> tag. This is a reflected injection of HTML/JavaScript into API output. If a client (web UI or other consumer) renders this error message into a web page without proper escaping/encoding (for example via innerHTML), it would lead to a reflected XSS execution in users' browsers. The server is echoing unescaped input in error messages; while the JSON response itself is not executable, the reflected script tag in the message demonstrates a clear XSS vector when combined with unsafe client-side rendering. Recommend sanitizing/escaping user input in error messages and avoiding reflection of raw input.", "evidence": "GraphQL error message: \"Expected value of type \\\"SerieFilters\\\", found \\\"<script>alert('xss')</script>\\\".\"", "confidence": 0.8, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "xss_injection", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.8, "evidence": "GraphQL error message: \"Expected value of type \\\"SerieFilters\\\", found \\\"<script>alert('xss')</script>\\\".\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response error includes the raw user-supplied string containing a <script> tag. This is a reflected injection of HTML/JavaScript into API output. If a client (web UI or other consumer) renders this error message into a web page without proper escaping/encoding (for example via innerHTML), it would lead to a reflected XSS execution in users' browsers. The server is echoing unescaped input in error messages; while the JSON response itself is not executable, the reflected script tag in the message demonstrates a clear XSS vector when combined with unsafe client-side rendering. Recommend sanitizing/escaping user input in error messages and avoiding reflection of raw input."}}]

[{"detection_name": "LLM: html_injection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL error message reflects user-supplied HTML markup including an event handler (
ClickMe
) back in the JSON response. This is clear evidence of HTML being returned verbatim by the server. If a client (web UI, error viewer, or any consumer) inserts that error message into a DOM without proper encoding/escaping, the injected markup and JavaScript could execute (client-side DOM XSS). Even though the payload appears inside a JSON string, the presence of raw HTML with an onclick handler is sufficient to create an HTML injection/XSS vector when consumed insecurely. Recommend treating all reflected content as untrusted: validate/normalize input, escape/HTML-encode error messages before rendering in HTML contexts, and avoid reflecting raw user input in error messages.", "evidence": "Error message contains unescaped HTML: \"Expected value of type \\\"SerieFilters\\\", found \\\"
ClickMe
\\\".\"", "confidence": 0.8, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "html_injection", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.8, "evidence": "Error message contains unescaped HTML: \"Expected value of type \\\"SerieFilters\\\", found \\\"
ClickMe
\\\".\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL error message reflects user-supplied HTML markup including an event handler (
ClickMe
) back in the JSON response. This is clear evidence of HTML being returned verbatim by the server. If a client (web UI, error viewer, or any consumer) inserts that error message into a DOM without proper encoding/escaping, the injected markup and JavaScript could execute (client-side DOM XSS). Even though the payload appears inside a JSON string, the presence of raw HTML with an onclick handler is sufficient to create an HTML injection/XSS vector when consumed insecurely. Recommend treating all reflected content as untrusted: validate/normalize input, escape/HTML-encode error messages before rendering in HTML contexts, and avoid reflecting raw user input in error messages."}}]

[{"detection_name": "LLM: Introspection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response returns detailed schema-related error messages that reveal type and field names (e.g., Query.series, Serie). Although this is not the __schema introspection query itself, these errors provide attackers with schema information that can be used to enumerate types/fields and craft targeted queries \u2014 effectively enabling schema discovery (introspection-like behavior). This is an information disclosure risk. Recommended mitigations: disable detailed error messages in production, sanitize or genericize GraphQL errors, restrict or disable introspection in production environments, implement query depth/complexity limits and use persisted queries or authentication/authorization checks to reduce exposure.", "evidence": "\"Unknown argument \\\"name\\\" on field \\\"Query.series\\\".\" and \"Cannot query field \\\"fields\\\" on type \\\"Serie\\\".\"", "confidence": 0.8, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "Introspection", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.8, "evidence": "\"Unknown argument \\\"name\\\" on field \\\"Query.series\\\".\" and \"Cannot query field \\\"fields\\\" on type \\\"Serie\\\".\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response returns detailed schema-related error messages that reveal type and field names (e.g., Query.series, Serie). Although this is not the __schema introspection query itself, these errors provide attackers with schema information that can be used to enumerate types/fields and craft targeted queries \u2014 effectively enabling schema discovery (introspection-like behavior). This is an information disclosure risk. Recommended mitigations: disable detailed error messages in production, sanitize or genericize GraphQL errors, restrict or disable introspection in production environments, implement query depth/complexity limits and use persisted queries or authentication/authorization checks to reduce exposure."}}]

simple_results: [{"detection_name": "Introspection Enabled", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Information Disclosure", "description": "GraphQL introspection enabled - potential information disclosure", "evidence": "Found __schema in response data - introspection queries are allowed"}]
llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: Introspection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response includes the built-in introspection entry points and full type information (the __schema and related __Type / __Field objects). This indicates that GraphQL introspection is enabled and unauthenticated callers can enumerate the schema (queries, types and field names). Exposed schema information lets an attacker discover available queries, arguments and fields and craft targeted queries to extract data or probe for sensitive fields, increasing attack surface. Although this does not by itself prove data exfiltration, it is an information disclosure risk and can significantly aid further exploitation. Recommended mitigations: disable introspection in production or restrict it to authenticated/authorized users, implement query depth/complexity limits and rate limiting, and enforce proper access controls on resolvers so schema exposure does not result in unauthorized data access.", "evidence": "Response contains a __schema object and type definitions (e.g. \"__schema\": { \"queryType\": { \"name\": \"Query\" }, \"types\": [...] }, presence of __Type, __Field, and many application types such as \"Card\", \"Set\", \"Serie\" with their fields).", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "Introspection", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "Response contains a __schema object and type definitions (e.g. \"__schema\": { \"queryType\": { \"name\": \"Query\" }, \"types\": [...] }, presence of __Type, __Field, and many application types such as \"Card\", \"Set\", \"Serie\" with their fields).", "explanation": "The GraphQL response includes the built-in introspection entry points and full type information (the __schema and related __Type / __Field objects). This indicates that GraphQL introspection is enabled and unauthenticated callers can enumerate the schema (queries, types and field names). Exposed schema information lets an attacker discover available queries, arguments and fields and craft targeted queries to extract data or probe for sensitive fields, increasing attack surface. Although this does not by itself prove data exfiltration, it is an information disclosure risk and can significantly aid further exploitation. Recommended mitigations: disable introspection in production or restrict it to authenticated/authorized users, implement query depth/complexity limits and rate limiting, and enforce proper access controls on resolvers so schema exposure does not result in unauthorized data access."}}]

[{"detection_name": "LLM: field_suggestions", "detection": "potential", "category": "Unknown", "description": "The GraphQL response reveals internal schema details in error messages: it explicitly names the type and field (Set.releaseDate) and includes full path arrays (series -> <index> -> sets -> <index> -> releaseDate). This leaks that 'releaseDate' on type 'Set' is non-nullable and exposes the structure/indices of collections. Such detailed error/path information can be used by an attacker to enumerate schema fields and plan targeted queries or attacks. Recommend suppressing detailed GraphQL error messages in responses (return a generic error message to clients), avoid returning internal 'path' data to callers, enable error masking/logging only server-side, and consider making fields nullable or handling nulls safely so that internal resolver errors do not propagate schema details to clients.", "evidence": "\"message\": \"Cannot return null for non-nullable field Set.releaseDate.\" with \"path\": [\"series\", 0, \"sets\", 0, \"releaseDate\"] (repeated across many series/sets) and data containing nulls for sets entries", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "field_suggestions", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "\"message\": \"Cannot return null for non-nullable field Set.releaseDate.\" with \"path\": [\"series\", 0, \"sets\", 0, \"releaseDate\"] (repeated across many series/sets) and data containing nulls for sets entries", "explanation": "The GraphQL response reveals internal schema details in error messages: it explicitly names the type and field (Set.releaseDate) and includes full path arrays (series -> <index> -> sets -> <index> -> releaseDate). This leaks that 'releaseDate' on type 'Set' is non-nullable and exposes the structure/indices of collections. Such detailed error/path information can be used by an attacker to enumerate schema fields and plan targeted queries or attacks. Recommend suppressing detailed GraphQL error messages in responses (return a generic error message to clients), avoid returning internal 'path' data to callers, enable error masking/logging only server-side, and consider making fields nullable or handling nulls safely so that internal resolver errors do not propagate schema details to clients."}}]
